thread.title: McHenry County reports first pediatric RSV death of 2024 as uptick in cases continue
thread.title_full: McHenry County reports first pediatric RSV death of 2024 as uptick in cases continue

author: Alonzo Small
title: McHenry County reports first pediatric RSV death of 2024 as uptick in cases continue
text:
WGN Chicago McHenry County reports first pediatric RSV death of 2024 as uptick in cases continue Alonzo Small Fri, December 20, 2024 at 12:52 AM UTC 1 min read
McHenry County reports first pediatric RSV death of 2024 as uptick in cases continue MCHENRY COUNTY, Ill. — Officials in McHenry County reported its first pediatric death attributed to Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) of the 2024 surveillance season.
Announced Thursday by its health department, McHenry County officials say the highly contagious virus has seen increased activity in children through age four, though it is not yet peak season.
The current transmission level is classified as moderate.
Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement More Coverage: WGN’s Medical Watch
RSVY symptoms include mild, cold-like symptoms such as congestion, a runny nose, irritability, decreased appetite, and fever.
Severe symptoms of RSV in babies can include short, shallow, and abnormally fast breathing, a wheezing cough, nasal flaring, difficulty feeding due to breathing difficulties, unusual tiredness, a blue tint to the lips or fingernails, and fever.
The McHenry County Department of Health used this incident to encourage parents and caregivers to seek medical care immediately if they notice these severe symptoms. Prevention tips include practicing good hand hygiene by washing hands regularly, cleaning frequently touched surfaces, and avoiding close contact with infants when sick.
Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Additional information on the RSV vaccine can be found by clicking here .
Last month, McHenry County health officials reported an uptick in whooping cough cases , adding that school-aged children accounted for the ‘significant increase’ of the highly contagious bacterial respiratory disease.
Duchenne muscular dystrophy patients receive new hope with gene therapy
Pertussis, also known as whopping cough, starts with mild symptoms, such as a runny nose and low-grade fever, before advancing to coughing fits, vomiting, or even pauses in breathing.
